advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, the personal micro which has talents of a pro"...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"I did click" <br><br> Cool french young boy, proud of its brand new Adam. Only the expansion module #3 version was available in France...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, FEB 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> CORTEX has been designed not to dominate your desk, to leave room for your calendar, your telephone, your in-tray and the rest. If you want it inconspicuous, buy iy in conventional cream. But for extroverts, and the fashion conscious, CORTEX comes in bright, bright colours - warm red, C/WP green, sunshine yellow, ice white and all black...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert was for the Serie 5 and the ACS-8000 systems.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #12</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RADIOLA ADVERT. 2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1978)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> ...You will get more performances than with the IBM PC, the Apple II, TRS80 Model II or TRS80 Model III along with software support of TRSDOS or CP/M, the two most widely used operating systems. This means you, the user, can select from the largest base of business or personal software... <font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Karl-Heinz - www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  ACORN AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> This attractive package inherits the traditions of the famous Model B BBC microcomputer which is used by children in almost every school in the United Kingdom as well as colleges, hospitals, laboratories, factories, offices, banks and shops. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Learn computers with a cool teacher" <br><br> "Alice, the Basic teacher"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"the power of words depends on the way you use them"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Japanese selling price was of 58.000 yen.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #3 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>As harware arguments wasn't sufficient, NothStar tried to promote software compatability and services.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SALES CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this catalog, NEWMAN COMPUTER EXCHANGE from Ann Arbor sold various Interact packages, from $44.95 for an incomplete and inoperative 8K model, to $299.95 for a 16K system along with 30 software cassettes and a complete documentation including the service manuals set. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #2 FEB. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br><font color="#666666"> These 35-track, 51/4" double-density drives will give you the high-level performance you want from your Color Computer. Each drive puts over 156K of on-line data and program storage right at your fingertips. And you can chain up to four drives together for a total of more than 626K. <br><br> Yet all that extra storage is available at a seek time of 30 milliseconds and a data transfer rate of 250 bits per second...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SIL'Z III</strong></font><br><blockquote>Nice fish-eye picture of a Sil'z III illustrating a 1982 article about Technologic Revolution in the french mag TeleSoft.</blockquote>

computer.description:
Little is known about this obscure professional computer.
The Athena used a true multi-tasking OS that enabled single keystroke application switching. It also incorporated intelligent distributed multiprocessing into perpherial interfaces.
The machine and OS were developed by an MIT graduate and conceived by Solid State Technology from Boston. The Athena is based on a 8085 Intel chipset. Sold with a monochrome monitor and 5.25'' disk drives (320 KB each), it has also a printer (150 characters/s, 80 col.) built-in the case.
Several programming languages were available : compiled BASIC, COBOL, FORTRAN, PASCAL and APL.
Fewer than one thousand of these machines were produced. The company never gained viability.
computer.name: Athena
